content: The President appoints individuals to federal positions, some with Senate approval. This report details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions during the 112th Congress, including leadership profiles and membership information. The report details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions during the 112th Congress, including membership information, terms of office, political balance requirements, and appointment activity. The report details nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions during the 112th Congress, including membership information, terms of office, political balance requirements, and appointment activity. The Federal executive branch boards and commissions discussed in this report share common characteristics such as being independent bodies located outside executive departments, having multiple members appointed by the President, and having at least one full-time member. The report discusses nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions during the 112th Congress. Members are appointed by the President with Senate approval, serve fixed terms, and have staggered end dates to ensure leadership continuity. The report discusses nominations for full-time positions on 34 boards and commissions during the 112th Congress, aiming to ensure leadership continuity through staggered end dates. Nominations can be made to complete unexpired terms or upcoming terms, with the possibility of simultaneous nominations for different terms. The chair on some commissions requires Senate confirmation and must be appointed from the incumbent commissioners. The President can appoint someone not on the commission as chair by submitting two nominations simultaneously - one for member and one for chair. Executive branch boards and commissions have political independence from the President, but he can influence membership by designating the chair or filling vacancies. President George W. Bush shaped the Securities and Exchange Commission and National Labor Relations Board by filling vacancies during his first two years in office. During the 112th Congress, President Obama submitted nominations for 63 out of 149 positions on the National Labor Relations Board due to vacancies, expiring recess appointments, and resignations. Some boards have limits on the number of members from the same political party, and advice and consent requirements apply to certain appointments. President Barack H. Obama submitted 76 nominations for 63 full-time positions on 34 regulatory and other boards and commissions during the 112th Congress. Of these nominations, 45 were confirmed, 8 were withdrawn, and 23 were returned to the President. Multiple nominations were submitted for some positions, including for individuals receiving recess appointments. During the 112th Congress, President Obama made 76 nominations for 63 positions on various boards and commissions. 45 nominations were confirmed, 8 were withdrawn, and 23 were returned. At the end of the Congress, 26 incumbents were serving past their terms, with 20 vacancies. The average time for confirmation was 156.0 days, with a median of 130.0 days. The mean confirmation time for nominations during the 112th Congress was 156.0 days, with a median of 130.0 days. Each board or commission profile in the report includes sections on leadership structure, membership, and appointment actions during the Congress. The "End of the 112th Congress" and "Appointment Action in the 112th Congress" sections identify agencies' positions requiring Senate confirmation and the incumbents in those positions as of the end of the 112th Congress. Incumbents serve fixed terms and their party affiliation is listed as Democrat (D), Republican (R), or Independent (I). Pay levels for presidentially appointed positions requiring Senate confirmation fall under the Executive Schedule. Level V is for the lowest-ranked positions, with most chair positions at level III and other positions at level IV. The "Appointment Action" section provides details on nominations, including nominee names, positions, submission and confirmation dates, and actions taken. Sometimes, multiple nominations are submitted for the same nominee to complete unexpired terms or for full terms. During the 112th Congress, the President submitted follow-up nominations to comply with requirements for recess appointments. Tables show mean days to confirm nominations, calculated by averaging confirmation dates. Appendix A provides detailed information on nominations for various positions. Appendix A provides detailed information on nominations and appointments to regulatory and other collegial boards and commissions during the 112th Congress. Tables include confirmation dates, withdrawn nominations, recess appointments, and mean and median confirmation times. Table A-2 summarizes appointments and nominations by organization for 34 independent boards and commissions. The Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission are independent agencies with members appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Members serve five-year terms, with specific rules for reappointment and replacement. The Consumer Product Safety Commission, Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board, and Election Assistance Commission each have specific rules for member appointments and terms. The number of members, term lengths, and political party restrictions vary for each agency. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission consists of five members serving five-year terms, with no more than three from the same political party. Incumbents can continue until a successor is appointed, with restrictions on serving after term expiration. The President designates the chair, vice chair, and general counsel. The Bank Board of Directors is composed of the bank president as chair, the first vice president as vice chair, and three other members appointed by the President. Terms are up to four years, with the option to continue until a successor is qualified. The President appoints an inspector general with Senate approval. The Farm Credit Administration has three members serving six-year terms, with restrictions on reappointment. The Federal Communications Commission, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Board of Directors, and Bank Board of Directors have members serving specific terms, with the option to continue until a successor is appointed. The President designates the chair for each board. The Federal Election Commission consists of six members, with no more than three from the same political party, serving a single six-year term. The chair and vice chair, from different parties and elected by the commission, change annually. The Regulatory Commission, Federal Labor Relations Authority, and Federal Maritime Commission each consist of members serving five-year terms, with limitations on political party representation. The President designates the chair for each commission. The Federal Maritime Commission, Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission, Federal Reserve System Board of Governors, and Federal Trade Commission each have a specific number of members serving fixed terms, with varying rules on political balance and chair designation by the President. The Federal Trade Commission has five members serving seven-year terms, with the President designating the chair. The Financial Stability Oversight Council has 10 voting members, chaired by the Secretary of the Treasury, with 9 serving ex officio and one appointed by the President for a six-year term. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, located in the Department of Justice, consists of three members serving three-year terms. The Merit Systems Protection Board consists of three members serving seven-year terms, with no more than two from the same political party. The President appoints the chair of both commissions with the advice and consent of the Senate. The National Credit Union Administration Board of Directors, National Labor Relations Board, and National Mediation Board consist of members serving specific terms, with political balance considerations. The President designates the chair for each board. The National Transportation Safety Board, Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and other boards consist of members serving specific terms, with political balance considerations. The President appoints the chair and other positions with Senate approval. The Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, Postal Regulatory Commission, and Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board each consist of members serving six-year terms, with political balance considerations. The President designates the chair and other positions, with specific rules for term expiration and succession. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, established by the Implementing Recommendations of the 9/11 Commission Act of 2007, consists of four part-time members serving six-year terms. The Railroad Retirement Board has three members serving five-year terms. The President appoints the chair and an inspector general with the advice and consent of the Senate for various boards such as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Surface Transportation Board. Members serve five-year terms and may continue until a successor is appointed. The United States International Trade Commission consists of six members serving nine-year terms, with the President designating the chair and vice chair for two-year terms. The United States Parole Commission is an independent agency with five commissioners serving six-year terms. The United States Sentencing Commission consists of seven voting members appointed by the President for six-year terms, with a limitation of serving no more than 12 years. The commission was previously scheduled to be phased out but has been extended multiple times by Congress. The chair and three vice chairs serve full time. The United States Sentencing Commission consists of seven voting members appointed by the President for six-year terms, with a limitation of serving no more than 12 years. The chair and three vice chairs, selected from among the members, serve full time. The President appoints the chair, with the advice and consent of the Senate, and designates the vice chairs. At least three members must be federal judges, with restrictions on political party affiliations and term limits. The Attorney General serves as a nonvoting member, along with the chair of the United States Parole Commission. Appendix A.
